Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Small: Collaborative Research: Competition, Neurality and Service Quality in Cellular Wireless Access

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The network neutrality debate has raised many issues of fair competition, revenue generation,  and the role of emerging technology. In the current public-commodity, data-networking marketplace, different competing Internet Service Providers (ISPs) presently have the option to act neutrally with respect to content and application-services  from remote 'content providers' (CPs). Also, competition and cooperation issues not directly  related to neutrality need to be addressed, e.g., roaming charges for small entrant cellular-wireless ISPs. These issues have direct bearing on availability and prices that ordinary consumers face. To better understand these important issues, this project aims to investigate models of competition and cooperation that integrate economic, regulatory and networking factors, particularly those of the still growing cellular-wireless context with its complex channel quality dynamics.

One research thrust is to assess if there are any real economic advantages for an ISP when acting non-neutrally for different models of interaction between ISPs and CPs. To this end, this project will jointly consider different types of cellular wireless data-plans typically involving some type of quota, subscription frameworks and advertising revenues of CPs, side-payments between ISPs and remote CPs manifest through service-level agreements at gateways to the (last-mile) ISP, and the physical-layer controls (e.g., transmission power) enacted by the ISP to service the wireless traffic according to different priorities and quality-of-service requirements. It will also consider the problem of promotion of competition between like providers to reduce consumer costs, particularly how to regulate roaming charges to encourage entrant cellular-wireless access providers. In addition, the project aims to investigate how best to leverage available types of real-world operational data, both econometric and workload (packet-traffic), to inform the investigators' models.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Network neutrality regulations continue to be debated astheir core economic issues constitute a topic of active research.The debate concerns all participants in the enormous andgrowing public-commodity Internet economy: residential/cellular-wirelessInternet service (access) providers (ISPs), contentproviders (CPs and CDNs, but more generally providers of application services),end-users/consumers, and government regulators. Proponents of network neutrality claim that non-neutrality discourages innovation on the CP side, decreases the competition among CPs, reinforces ISP oligopolies, and undermines the so called ``free Internet". On the other hand, those who advocate relaxing network neutrality rules claim that neutrality, as it is perceived commonly,  is a barrier to further developments on the Internet since it discourages ISPs from investing in their costly last-mile infrastructure (including spectrum licenses) and managed services. This debate has largely been conducted on a qualitative level without rigorous economic and technical analyzes. This is the deficit that this project has redressed. 

 

The project has characterized the optimal and equlibria  strategies of different entities in the cellular-wireless internet marketplace, namely the content provider (CP), internet service provider (ISP) and end user (EU) in presence of: 1) service differentiation in a marketplace comprising of entities of different nature 2) advertising revenue and side payments 3) competition between providers providing similar services but operating under different paradigms, namely neutral or non-neutral. It has provided an analytically tractable framework for assessing the benefits of non-neutrality from the perspective of various participants, namely CP, ISP, EU in arbitrary wireless internet markets. The framework has been utilized through extensive analysis and numerical computations to provide founded insights on the operations of the system and guidance to the participants as to the various choices that confront them. The formulations rely on parsimonious hierarchical game-theoretic models, both the formulations and the solutions are novel in context of game-theory and wireless networks. Thus, the project enriches both 1) the application domain of wireless networks, or more specifically economics of wireless networks, by providing solutions to the pressing problems confronting the field, and 2) the field of game theory by introducing novel formulations motivated by pressing needs in the application domain and the solution techniques.    The results have been disseminated in premius conferences and journals in the research field, a list of publications can be obtained in https://neutrality.seas.upenn.edu/ 

 

The project has  supported the education of  doctoral students at the Universityof Pennsylvania and Penn State University, who have successfully  graduated. They have subsequently assumed academic and practice positions at reputed Universities and data-science industry.  The project has also educated masters students   who have  subsequently joined the doctoral program at the respective institutions.

The research conducted as part of this project has allowed the Principal investigators  to enrich advanced courses at graduate and undergraduate levels. These courses train students in the science of networks, spanning   a diverse set of networks, namely social networks, communication networks, power networks, transportation networks,  biological networks and pandemic control, etc.  


The Principal investigators  have been active in various fora in the University of Pennsylvania and the Penn State University towards enhancing the participation  of under-represented minorities in the STEM field.
